Award.AwardTitle: Pathways for Alternative Energy Automotive Technicians

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a growing need for well-educated highly skilled technicians with practical knowledge of alternative energy automotive systems. The Columbus State Community College (CSCC) "Pathways for Alternative Energy Automotive Technicians" project addresses local workforce needs for technicians that are knowledgeable about such systems. Given innovations in the automotive alternative energy industry and the increased computerization of automotive systems, the traditional training of automotive technicians must be updated to equip them for today's industry needs. Areas of need include conventional hybrid, plug-in hybrid, all-electric vehicle technologies as well as biodiesel, propane, ethanol, compressed natural gas, liquefied natural gas, and fuel-cell vehicles. This project will also address an impending workforce shortage among automotive dealers in central Ohio who have a need for new 21st Century technicians to meet an upcoming wave of retirement among today's mid-career mechanics.

In the project, CSCC will be developing a new career pathway and new curricula in Alternative Energy Automotive Technology with the help of a dedicated industry-based leadership team. The rigorous curriculum will include key topics from the sciences, automotive technology, engineering and mathematics, all essential for the preparation of the future technical workforce. As technicians must have strong hands-on diagnostic skills, project-based learning will be employed liberally throughout the curriculum. In addition to the new curricula at the college level, pre-college faculty will be exposed to emerging trends in alternative energy automotive technology to aid the recruitment of high school graduates. Additionally, from a safety perspective, first responders will be trained to deal with hazardous aspects of hybrid and alternative fuel technology. CSCC will be working in collaboration with several partners in the region including Clean Fuels Ohio, the Center for Automotive Research at The Ohio State University, local high school districts and technical centers and industry partners. The project will build upon the results of previously funded NSF project at the Center for Aviation and Automotive Technical Education using Virtual E-School (CA2VES) at Clemson University and the South Carolina Advanced Technological Education, National
Center (SCATE).

POR.DRECONTENT:
AUTO Outcomes Report

Through the Pathways for Alternative-Energy Automotive Technicians project, Columbus State Community College developed a tailored career pathway, in partnership with a highly engaged industry leadership team. The program optimizes emerging techniques and technologies including project-based learning, integrated learning objects, simulations, and a STEM-intensive curriculum that incorporates technology, engineering, automotive, and mathematics.

Alternative-energy vehicles (hybrid, electric, and natural gas) are rapidly becoming more prevalent in Central Ohio ? in part through the Smart Columbus initiative, funded by the U.S. Department of Transportation Smart City Challenge. The newly developed Alternative-Energy Automotive Technology curriculum at Columbus State will meet the growing regional demand for technicians who are highly skilled and knowledgeable. In addition to producing a cutting-edge curriculum, the project provided invaluable training workshops for first responders and automotive instructors across Ohio.

Key project accomplishments include:

1) Enhancing four existing courses with robust alternative-energy content, leading to an AAS degree in Automotive Technology. These courses prepare students to test for National Coalition of Certification Centers (NC3) certifications to further increase their marketability to employers. Throughout the project, 254 students enrolled in the four modified courses and achieved 350 total NC3 certifications. Additionally, 14 of those students earned an automotive AAS, and Columbus State awarded 70 automotive certificates to 54 individuals, including one Master Automotive Service Technician certificate.

2) Launching three new courses leading to a newly developed Alternative-Energy Automotive Technician certificate. Columbus State partnered with the City of Columbus to sponsor a cohort of eight technicians to complete the program, gaining the skills to effectively manage Columbus? growing fleet of alternatively fueled vehicles.

3) Providing two Alternative-Fueled Vehicle Extrication workshops for first responders from around Ohio. Columbus State?s Automotive Technology and Fire Science departments collaborated to create and host the summer workshops in 2018 and 2019. Through classroom instruction and hands-on labs, first responders learned from experienced faculty and a 30-year veteran of The City of Columbus Division of Fire about alternative-energy vehicle systems and how to safely perform extrications on these vehicles. Fifty-one total first responders participated in the training, and several Ohio fire departments are exploring replicating the training in-house.

4) Hosting two Automotive Instructors Workshops for educators from across the state to learn about emerging trends in alternative-energy automotive technology and to enhance their skills through immersive labs. Attendance from 2018 to 2019 grew 53 percent, from 38 instructors to 58. Ford was a primary sponsor for the 2019 workshop and provided full-sized hybrid and electric vehicles for hands-on instruction.

5) Acquiring essential equipment to enhance education for learners of all ages and stages at Columbus State. Key items include a compressed natural gas (CNG) filling station, an AutoARK H2 Generator, CNG training components, a Hybrid Vehicle Systems Panel Trainer, and several hybrid and electric vehicles.

The Pathways for Alternative-Energy Automotive Technicians project at Columbus State has successfully created a career pathway in alternative-energy automotive technology, while promoting awareness and education throughout Ohio. Not only does the program develop students? skills for success in the workforce, but has also enhanced the knowledge and abilities of first responders and automotive instructors across the state. Though the project period has ended, Columbus State will continue to promote alternative-energy automotive education and respond to the industry?s demand for a highly skilled and adaptable workforce.

Find more information about this project and Columbus State Community College?s continued work with NSF?s Advanced Technological Education program here.
